FacilityName: Marine Corps Air Station - Cherry Point

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
4.1 Executive Summary

Marine Corps Air Station (MCAS) Cherry Point?s accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are to maintain safe conditions for base personnel and the inhabitants of the surrounding communities.  This policy is to be enforced through strict compliance with applicable regulations, physical safeguards, rigorous training, and deployment of adequate resources.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response are given the highest priority.

The Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990 required the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to formulate regulations for managing and reducing the probability of release of highly hazardous chemicals.  On June 20, 1996, EPA promulgated the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule (40 CFR 68) requiring any stationary source utilizing greater than a specified threshold quantity of a regulated substance to develop and submit a Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) to regulatory authorities on or before June 21, 1999.  Regulated substances include 77 air toxics and 63 flammable gases or liquids.

MCAS Cherry Point has one process subject to EPA RMP regulations:

?- Chlorine storage, handling, and use at the water treatment plant (WTP)

Chlorine is used in excess of their threshold quantities of 2,500 pounds.  Chlorine is stored in one-ton containers and used in the treatment of drinking water at the WTP.  

This RMPlan summarizes the primary components of the RMP in place at MCAS Cherry Point to correspond with specific EPA RMP requirements, including:

?- Management ? A separate document, the ?Compliance Management Plan for Clean Air Act Section 112(r) Risk Management Program? details specific requirements for a management system under 40 CFR 68.15.

?- Hazard Assessment ? The Hazard Assessment assessed a WCS and ARS with the only active mitigation being excess flow values.  Thus a true worst-case scenario was represented.  Additionally, there have been no chlorine accidents at the WTP since it was

built over 10 years ago.

?- Prevention Program 3 ? Cherry Point has implemented all elements of Preventio Program 3 and has taken special steps to enclose chlorine areas and install chlorine monitors to prevent releases.

?- Emergency Response Program ? Cherry Point has a detailed ERP for chlorine releases.  The Fire Department is the first responder in the event of a release ? WTP employees do not respond to chlorine releases.  The ERP also includes communication with regulatory and other response agencies as well as first aid information.

?- Planned Changes to Improve Safety ? Resulting from Cherry Point?s most recent PHA (conducted 08/16/2006), the WTP plans to investigate  options to improve safety.
